turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Mummy and I, we were more like lovers, really, or sisters.  Then a couple of years after Daddy died, and not long after I left Oxford, she started seeing various men and I was furious.  I really was upset. I stopped going home.  I never phoned.  I went round telling everyone how awful her books were. And she hardly seemed to notice, and that made me angrier.  Then I got a job I was interested in, and I started to see lots of men, and I suppose I grew up a little and began to understand.  So I wrote her a long letter, almost seven pages, saying how sorry I was, and how I was worried that we were drifting apart.  And do you know, she wrote me a poem, a really beautiful poem about mothers and daughters.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: How nice.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It makes me weepy just to remember it.  So we were fine again, and then she got married to Matthew who's a womaniser and a bit of a yob, but quite nice really, makes TV commercials.  What about yours.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Both dead.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: That must be rather nice, in a way.  I mean, you don't have any--

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Damn.  They're early.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I called you a taxi.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Very thoughtful.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, you know...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Again?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes, if you like.  Call me at work.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Why not stay?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I have to be up early.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Two or three years ago I would have stayed.  And fucked you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Too late.  Just my luck.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You don't trust me.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't trust anyone.  That's what comes of working in television.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: In radio we're different.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I bet.  Thanks for the drink.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I might see you in Norfolk over the weekend.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You just might.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I think we're ready now, thank you.  And how was Norfolk?  Did you get on with my mother?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I think she liked me.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Did she talk about me?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No.  We talked about history, and Siberian Geese.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Do you think she's invited you up for her sake or for mine?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I haven't really thought about it.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, you should.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I haven't seen much of you.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No.  It's a bit of a madhouse. For some reason a lot of my mother's friends specialise in monologues.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: He's all right, the professor.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Look, will you come on a walk with me tomorrow?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I might.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Might?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Might?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes.  Might.  Remember, you're here to talk to my mother.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Jeremy phoned this morning

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What did he want?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: He's making plans for Brighton. He thought we could travel down together.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: That'll be fun

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: In your car

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Why not.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Shall we have a drink or something?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh ... excuse me.  There's Nicholas.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: We don't seem to get much time to talk.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I know.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Not here.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: To the airlift.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: To the airlift.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Any sign of the goddess Barrington?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Not yet you know any of these people?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: One or two.  A grey lot.  Some social democrats.  Some diligent anti-communists.  A political section man from the US Embassy. And this exquisite Californian wine, courtesy of the CIA.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Nonsense.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Blasé and epicene.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: We were just chortling over that. Blasé and epicene.  It perfectly describes the new Foreign Secretary. So--I hope you don't mind, Edward, I pinched it for my piece today.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: C'mon.  I don't want any Jones about this.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: No jokes.  James is in love.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Bastard.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Name so Susie Barrington.  Daughter of the eminent historian, Anne Barrington, step-daughter of the scandalous Matthew Byrd the acclaimed sack-artist...

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: To the Fleet.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: To the Fleet.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: And the Argies.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: The Argies.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Now, top secret file.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Come on.  Hand over.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Uh-huh.  Tell me what you think of this first.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's shit.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You approve!

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Let me see.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Get way.  You'll see when I'm ready. First I want you to reflect on my noble behaviour, on how your interests are closest to my heart, how I lay awake at night worrying--

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Jeremy, just let me see what you've got.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You're so hard.  All right then. I was chatting to some people from the diary page, and the name of Barrington came up.  I expressed an interest...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Oh yes.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: ...an innocent interest, and found out that last year Vogue ran a series called 'Mothers and Daughters' Number seven, Anne and Susan Barrington.  Being a decent loving friend I went to the files and made a copy for you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Let me see.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Ah, ah.  There's more.  The piece celebrates the undying affection between eminent left-wing historian and he dazzling daughter.  Then the news editor, who happened to be in the room, said that years ago, when he worked on The Guardian, Anne Barrington had written a very good piece on...guess...Suez.  It was 1966, the tenth anniversary.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: She's never written a book in it, but she clearly knew a lot.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Mmm...

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: It's obvious what you have to do. Your way into the daughter's pants is through the mother, up the Suez canal...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're so gross.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: She's very nice, apparently.  Lives in Norfolk.  And very left-wing. You'll have to watch yourself there.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Ha ha...

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: According to this, the daughter goes up to stay quiet often.  You'll need to get yourself invited for the right weekend.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You've really got it all worked out, haven't you?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: No need to thank me, if you don't want to.  Just pay for these drinks.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: That's enough of that.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: We've been playing ten minutes for Christ sake.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Far too long.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What have you been up to?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Well, everyone's desperate for a new Falkland's angle.  Purdy's come up with a real dog.  Worker's rights in Argentina.  So I've been running round getting people to do things.  But no one's keen.  Workers rights.  When did anyone on that paper give a damn about workers rights?  I said to Purdy, "Look, tits, bingo, jingo, horoscope, sport, celebs, gossip and the occasional firm stand on--"

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: The torture of small children--

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: On the torture of very small children, but don't start telling them about their rights--

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Hold those rights.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Tame those rights...you know, we're even freighting in a couple of exiled Argie trade unionists from Paris for a TV tie in.  One of them had his balls tap-danced on by the secret police.  The other one had to be hosed off the wall of his cell after the police-- yes my good man?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Fortunate that I was here to keep Susan entertained.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Sorry.  Got held up.  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Delivering gossip and goodwill. It seems we'll both be doing Brighton.  Perhaps you should come too.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Will it be fun?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Perhaps I will, then.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I'm off.  Let's meet.  You promised to tell me about Norfolk.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'll ring you.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Still in love?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Six onion bajees!  Great girl.  Did you shake the mother off?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes, finally.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Big mistake, I think.  You might have learned a lot.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Are you up to something?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Susan and I are very old friends, James.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Fuck off.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: And you were obviously getting nowhere with her.  I was waiting for the right moment to tell you that.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: My God.  You even cooked up that Norfolk trip.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: It might have worked.  Really.  I would have been delighted for you if it had.  But she wasn't interested.  Not my fault.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're a piece of shit

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: I've known Susan for more than fifteen years.  James, we're old allies.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'm waiting for your mother.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She said awfully sorry, make yourself comfortable, she won't be long. .

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why not sit down and wait?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Okay, I will.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She's not my mother, anyway.  My mother's in Italy.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Oh, I see.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Have you come to talk about me?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Not at all.  History.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What period?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Suez.  1956.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Do you want to hear my list of English Kings and Queens?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It goes from Henry VIII.  Henry VIII, Edward IV, Mary, Elizabeth I, James I, Charles I, Charles II, James II, William and Mary, Ann, George I, II, III and IV, Victoria, Edward VII, George V, Edward VIII, George IV, Elizabeth II.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What about the Cromwells?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: They don't count.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Wait...and with talks at the United Nations still making little progress, tension and anxiety settled on MPs of all parties in Westminster.  Speaking on the Jimmy Young Show earlier today, Mrs Thatcher said the prospects of a peaceful solution did not look encouraging.  What is it?

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Take a look at these.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Not bad.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: Fifteen news items.  I got exactly the same running order as the bulletin desk.  They're all old pros.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: It's that lady from Norfolk again.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'm not here.

turns.speaker: PHILIP
turns.text: I'm terribly sorry.  He doesn't seem to be here ... No ... Yes, if I see him, I will. .. Goodbye. She's going to phone back.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Next time tell her I've gone away.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Hello, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Dad.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Come into the kitchen.  I'm just making your mother's tea.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: So how is she?

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Well, she doesn't complain much. You know what she's like.  She keeps asking when you're coming...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'm sorry about Saturday, Dad.  It was just impossible to get away.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Oh she knows you're very busy, especially now, with everything going on...the doctor said to try her on solids, but she's been right off her food...You take this up to her.  Tell her you made it.  She'll like that.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Everyone's been marvellous really, Jimmy.  The neighbours come and sit with her while I'm at work.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: And Joe Ramage - do you remember him?  He comes and helps out in the shop.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes, you said.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Now, are you going to have some more tea?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No, thanks Dad.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: Or a beer.  I've got some in.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I've got to be going.  I've got a meeting tonight.

turns.speaker: MR. PENFIELD
turns.text: The bed's all made up if you want to stay.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'll ring you in the next couple of days.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: I just might give you a ring when we get back to London.  There's one or two things I'd like to... Will you let me have your number before you leave?  Have you ever watched a commercial being made?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Well, it's worth seeing.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: I'll tell you another thing.  We might have led the world once into the Industrial Revolution, now we lead with television commercials. We're the best, it's as simple as that.  Even the Americans will admit it now ... the camera work, the acting, the scripts, special effects.  We've got the lot.  Nearly all the good directors here have ambitions to make serious films.  That food you're eating.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: What would you call it?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I dunno.  Ploughman's Lunch.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Ploughman's Lunch.  Traditional English fare.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: U-huh.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: In fact it's the invention of an advertising campaign they ran in the early sixties to encourage people to eat in pubs.  A completely successful fabrication of the past, the Ploughman's Lunch was.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Susan told me that your visits to Norfolk had ... well, an ulterior motive.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: She said that?

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: You weren't really interested in Suez at all.  Incredibly enough, you were interested in my wife.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Now listen...

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: No, no, let me go on before you get the wrong idea.  Ann and I have kept to our separate bedrooms for the last three years.  And I can't imagine that Susan hasn't hinted at the kind of life I lead in London.  I'm not telling you how to run your affairs.  I'm just saying ... I don't mind.  I'm giving you permission.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Jeremy!  How Fantastic.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Darling Susan.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're so famous now.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: And you're so beautiful.  What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: We're thinking of doing this current affairs thing for schools.  World history since 1945.  Twelve programmes, lots of stock film.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: In that case, you should meet my very dear friend, James Penfield. Brilliant analyst of recent history and a world authority on the Berlin Airlift.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It was last year.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: We might be able to dig out a couple of Suez survivors for you.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Darling Susan.  You look like an angel.  But where's your hat?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh no!

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: They won't let you in without one.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Don't point it at James!

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Voila!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What have you got there?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: You'd look naked without one.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, yes!  Where's mine?  I want to look like you.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: We'll see what we can do.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Promise?

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Promise.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It was incredible.  He came back, made a pompous little bow and said, 'My dear girl you may film me all afternoon if you wish.' And he's promised not to talk to the Press.

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: It's because he desires you.  The women get all the breaks at these conferences.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It's true!  I was here last year doing a piece, remember?  I was in the bar with all these Northern trade unionists and their sponsored MPs.  They were all incredibly fat and beery, huge trousers and braces. And so sweet.  They all stood round me like children saying 'You! Working for television?  You're just a young thing.'  They wouldn't let me buy drinks even when I told them the programme was paying. They kept looking at my pass which was pinned here and saying  'Oo, can I?'

turns.speaker: JEREMY
turns.text: Then one of them was sick all over your new dress.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No, he wasn't.  He just lowered himself into a bar stool and said...  'Oo I do feel bad.  I 'ad three pints of lager and six onion bajees!'

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Don't close the door.  Don't turn out the hall light.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I won't.  Goodnight.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: 'Night.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ah, Susy, it...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Tom . .. bed!  Go on.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Don't you want to walk, Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Actually, I've been once today already.  I'll stay here with him.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Something happened.  You got nuked in the last quarter.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Yeah, my knee got folded about 90 degrees the wrong way.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: And that's why you never went pro?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Two years of surgery.  I missed my window.  Limped through law school instead.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Mmm.  A lawyer, huh?  Too bad.  But at least you're surfing now.  So your life's not over yet, right?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Friends of yours, huh?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: The one you decked is Bunker Wiess. The big one is his brother, Warchild.  The other two always hang.  They think they're some kinda death squad around here.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: What's their program?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: They're punks.  Nazis.  Their brains are wired wrong.  They hurt surfing because they give nothing back, and they have no respect for the sea. They just want to get radical.  It's mindless aggression.  They'll never get it, the spiritual side of it.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You always talk like this?  You're not gonna start chanting or anything are you?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: No.  So I was up the beach.  I saw it going down.  you didn't hesitate... they never backed you up an inch. That's rare in this world.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Thanks for stepping in.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: De nada.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Gonna be some people at my house tonight.  Maybe you can make it.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Come with Tyler.  She knows.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Don't you gamble?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Only make bets I can't afford to lose.  Only way to be 100% committed.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: So what's the biggest?  Waimea?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: No, Bells Beach, Australia.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I gotta be fucking crazy.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Yeah, but are you crazy enough?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Football's a man-made game.  You keep score with numbers.  But in this, there's no field, no rules, no opponent.  Just you and the wave.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I know that part.  Tell me something I can use, here.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: I've watched you once or twice.  You surf like it's some kind of street fight.  You jerk along from moment to moment, fighting everything that comes at you.  Always trying to win.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: A flaw I'm working on.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: The only way to win out here is to surrender.  You have to feel what the wave is doing, accept its energy, get in sync.  Just feel it all moving in the blackness... you don't need to see.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Yeah, right, vision is highly over- rated.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: How you figure?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: News, last night... those guys, the Ex-Presidents... they robbed my bank yesterday.  And I was just there the day before, cashing a check.  See... look.  Assured Trust... same place.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: One shot stopping.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: 'One shot stopping'... good, very good.  I like you, Johnny.  I like you because you'll sacrifice anything to win.  I respect that. It elevates you a little above the drones who have learned compromise. Here, hold it.  Check out the weight.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Ever done this before?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Once.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Pure adrenalin, right?!  The ultimate rush.  Other guys snort for it, jab a vein for it -- all you gotta do is jump.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Sure, it's a blast, but listen, I sorta screwed up my knee yesterday--

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Yeah, I noticed you limping.  But don't worry about it, brah. Don't worry at all.  We're not gonna land on land!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: It's a little ceremony we always have at the end of summer.  One last speedstar.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: So, who... uh, who packed my chute?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: I did.  What's the matter?  Don't trust me?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You gotta earn trust.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Then we'll earn it together.  Here, take mine.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: We gonna jump or jerk off?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: My man!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Utah, you copy bruddah?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Whoooaaah!  Shhiiittt!  Whoooaaah!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: I'll take that as a yes.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: You gonna pull?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: After you, Alfonse.  I insist!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Don't screw around man, pull it!

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You do it... you first!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: One thousand feet.  Pull the goddamn cord!

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You first!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Okay!

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Insurance policy.  Now this is going to sting a bit, but it's for your own growth, brah.  Press play.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You're a fucking dead man--

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Whoa, whoa!!  Think it through!  I'm the only one knows where they are. Just let me talk for a second.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Talk.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: She'll be fine, Rosie won't do anything.  At least not as long as I meet him at a certain place and time, about... let's see...  ... six hours from now.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You call him... right now... and tell him to let her go.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Sorry, can't do it, brah.  He's on the road.  And where they're going there's no phones.  Damn, I hate this Johnny, I really do.  I hate violence.  See, that's why I need Rosie.  I could never make this thing work, myself.  No way I could hold a knife to Tyler's throat, man! She was my woman, once.  We shared time in this world.  But Rosie, he's kind of a... mechanism.  Once you set him in motion, he won't stop. That's his gift, a kind of... blankness.  Noon comes, straight up, he'll gut her like a pig and try not to get any on his shoes.  Nothing I can do, unless I get there.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: We're wasting time.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: See!  That's what I like about you, man!  You're just sharp as a razor blade.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I can't do this.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Sure you can!  You may even like it... it's a killer rush.  You'll see.  Hey, don't I show you things, Johnny U?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Bodhi, this is your wake up call, man -- I... am... an... Eff... Bee... Eye... Agent!!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Wild, ain't it?!  See, we exist on a higher plane, you and I.  We make our own rules.  Why be a servant of the law Johnny U... when you can be it's master?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I'm not armed.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: But you're not alone.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Good guess.  There's a gun on you right now.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Where's Roach?

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Around somewhere.  Listen, I'm in kind of a hurry, Johnny U.  What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: You gotta tell me where she is.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: And let my policy expire?  Sorry.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Look, Bodhi man.  People are dead. The ride is over.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: I say when it's over!

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: The guy you killed was an off duty cop!  If you get out of here they'll nail you wherever you land.  They have a new thing called radar. Maybe you've heard of it.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Why should I?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: What if your chute fails, Bodhi? Rescind the order.  Let her off the hook, she's served her purpose.  Do it, man, you owe me that much.  Let me hear it before you check out.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Pretty radical, Johnny.  Even for you.  Why don't you pull it?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: No games, Bodhi.  Pull the cord! Now!!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Naw, you pull it!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Go on, Johnny.  Pull it.  But you gotta drop the gun, first!  Right?! You use your other hand what you gonna hold on with?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Pull it right now or I'll blow your fucking head off and pull it myself!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Well that's the only way it's gonna happen, man.  Do it!  Come on, you want to do it.  You're gonna die, Johnny.  Five more seconds.  Four...

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Three seconds... two... one...

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: SHIT!!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: Wild ride, huh?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Bodhi!

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: And I always knew I could count on you, Agent Utah.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I'm not FBI anymore.

turns.speaker: BODHI
turns.text: You never were...

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I asked them to give me a couple minutes...

turns.speaker: FIBERGLASS
turns.text: Yeah?  What?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Have you seen a little dog?  Kind of a cockapoo lookin' thing.  About this big.

turns.speaker: FIBERGLASS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: You sure he isn't out back?  You mind if I go take a look?

turns.speaker: FIBERGLASS
turns.text: Look, I don't know anything about your dog, okay--

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Well is there anyone else here that might have seen him?

turns.speaker: FIBERGLASS
turns.text: There's nobody else here...

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: You know less than nothing.  If you even knew that you knew nothing, at least that would be something, but you don't.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Eating solid breakfasts, Utah?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: All the food groups?  Avoiding sugar?  Caffeine?  I see to it that my people maintain cardiovascular fitness.  We stay off hard liquor, cigarettes...

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: I take the skin off chicken.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: This is us.  Bank Robbery.  And you're in the bank-robbery capital of the world--

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: 1322 last year in LA county.  Up 26 percent from the year before.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: That's right.  And we nailed over a thousand of them.  We did it by crunching data.  Good crime-scene work, good lab work, good data-base analysis.  Nobody had to tackle a car once.  You getting the signal, special agent?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Zero distortion, sir.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: You're a real blue-flame special, aren't you, Utah?  I don't know why they sent you to LA.  Must be an asshole shortage.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Not so far.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: How was the beach?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Surf conditions okay?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: A little mushy.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: A little mushy!  You think the taxpayers would like it, Utah, if they knew they were paying a federal agent to surf and pick up girls?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Babes.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: The correct term is babes, sir.  Uh, this type of undercover operation is entirely dependent on picking up the idiom of the speech.  Otherwise penetration is not possible, sir. Of the social infrastructure, I mean.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Special Agent Utah, this is not some job flippin' burgers at the drive-in. Yes, the surfboard bothers me.  Yes, your approach to this case bothers me.  And yes, you bother me.  You two have produced squat in the last two weeks, during which time the Ex- Presidents have robbed two more banks!!  Do you have anything even remotely interesting to tell me?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Caught my first tube this morning.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Three men dead.  One of them a cop. How's that sit in your gut, Utah?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Take your hand off my shoulder right now.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: They found the drop car up on Mulholland.  I want you two to go work it.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: What?  Now I'm working the drop car? Who's handling the scene here?

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Cole and Munoz.  I'm uh... letting them run with the ball for a while.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Cole and Munoz?  I been on this case for two years.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: That's the point, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Yeah, I get it.  Time to play let's dick the old guys, huh, Harp?

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Supervising Special Agent, Harp. Now I want you to go work the drop car, okay, Angelo?  Okay?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Look, Harp.  Don't turn him over to the uniforms like some punk.  Let me ride him in.

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: Yeah, sure.  Why not?  You two screw-ups deserve each other. That's why I put you together in the first place.  Christ Pappas, you're as bad as he is... talk about the blind leading the blind--

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Harp, let me tell you something.  I was an agent in this bureau when your mommy was still wiping your shinny pink ass, and you know one thing I learned in all those years that you still haven't?

turns.speaker: HARP
turns.text: What that?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Added to which indignity, I got three months left to retirement and they saddle me with some blue-flamer fresh out of Quantico for a partner. Some quarterback punk, Johnny Unitas or something.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: The shit they pull, huh?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Pappas.  Angelo Pappas.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Punk.  Quarterback Punk.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Welcome to Sea World, kid.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Good move.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Yeah, they control the room well. Stick strictly to the cash drawers.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: They don't go for the vault?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Never go for the vault.  They never get greedy.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Smart.  You burn time in the vault.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Reagan usually drives.  Stolen switch car, they leave it running at the curb, looks parked from a distance.  When they run, they dump the vehicle and vanish.  And I mean vanish.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Surgical.  Look at them separate the dye packs.  Dick and Ronny know their jobs.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: The Ex-Presidents are the best I've seen, kid.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: You through, Mr. Wizard?  Let me know if you find Jimmy Hoffa under the seat while you're at it.  Hell, it's only 7:30.  The night's still young... you can solve this case and start on another one.

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Well, what're your ideas on these guys?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Forget about it, kid.  They're ghosts.  Let the goddamn yuppie Mormon affirmative action assholes handle it.  See I'm almost 55... so I must be senile, right?  They better get me out before I start pissing myself in public.  Drooling. It would look bad for the Bureau, right?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: So you're gonna coast to retirement, when you could nail these guys and go out with come dignity.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: You watch your fucking mouth!  Mr. Hoover himself pinned the Seal of Honor right here!

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: Yeah.  That was thirty years ago anyway.  L.A.'s changed a lot since then. The air got dirty and the sex got clean.  So you want to nail the Ex- Presidents?  Be a big hero?

turns.speaker: UTAH
turns.text: Yeah.  What's your theory?

turns.speaker: PAPPAS
turns.text: The fucking punks are surfers.
